Like an earlier commenter I think you're missing the point. The author is factually correct that a mother should never leave her child so early. Not to be a pedant, but I highly suspect it's stasistically correct that 99.9% of the time children are "unharmed" when left at daycares or at the care of others in scenarios similar to the one described by Karl's mother. "Harm" is wideranged from extreme cases like Karl's to something "innocuous" like minor scratches here and there from diper changes or other things. So it's more than you think.

Also, women (or rather mothers) are natural caretakers because the survival of children depends on them and their nursing (and also their instincts) and when work or anything comes between this (required) nursing it's really a problem.

The issue is really this: should a mother (or I suppose father in a reversed role, if the mother earns more or is 'bread winner'), HAVE to leave her child with someone else in the name of trying to pay bills. My answer is no...a mother should have the existential right to choose between taking care of her children or working. Or both (which is what many 'choose', or are forced to choose; unfortunately with terrible consequences at times).

So when the choices don't really exist, then yes, we must ask the next question: what is it about our culture or society, or way of life in general that deprives our women from having this fundamental choice?

You put parental leave against protecting the world, which is both simplistic and false.
Most of our defense spending is essentially public works programs that goes back into the American economy. Yes there are better ways, far better ways, to spend much of this money, like on infrastructure, but it's not a cogent argument to say we can't afford paid leave because we have to defend the world. Additionally, our defense spending pays financial dividends, historically, in increased business opportunities for American companies, not that that is a good reason for military actions, and this calculus has totally failed in Iraq.
Lastly, making it a right to have 6 months leave, instead of 6 weeks, wouldn't cost that much and would be a step in the right direction. It is not more efficient in the long run, in purely economic terms to force parents away from 2 month old babies.

I am very sorry for your loss.  My prayers and thoughts go out to you and your family.  I am a mom of an 8 week old and I was also facing the same dilemma as my 12 weeks maternity leave will end in a month.  Together with my husband I have made the decision that I will take a leave of absence from my job to care for our newborn until at least he is one year old.  We will pay for health insurance out of our pockets, while my husband continues to work as a freelancer, with unpredictable monthly income.  We're grateful that we have enough savings to get us through this coming year.  However, not many people can afford that choice.  I emailed all my local and state representatives to address the lack of parental leave in the US.

This may sound like it's off-topic (loss of a child, lack of healthcare options, lack of daycare options being the topic), but actually it's not. I recently watched an Oregon Public Broadcasting special on Oregon's preparedness for a Cascadia-subduction zone earthquake and its subsequent tsunami. The reporters interviewed one of the state's geologists who looked at one coastal town's lack of willingness to relocate their hospital out of the tsunami zone. This was contrasted with a segment about what Japan had done with their schools and hospitals: 1-they put them uphill, and 2-they put their hospitals on massive springs to prevent everything from shaking around during an earthquake.

As a science teacher in a high school located within the tsunami zone on the Oregon coast, hiking on flat ground for a full mile with my students in evacuation drills, I was actually floored by Japan's creativity and ingenuity and their ability to engineer themselves into a position of greater safety.

Not so, the voters here: they voted no to putting our K-12 system uphill.

They also voted no to retrofitting bridges, as well as other issues. There is no movement to improve our parks or pick up the tourists' trash and keep public restrooms clean in our tourist town.

Sometimes Oregon seems pervaded by a very deep apathy about taxes, infrastructure and engineering.

So to do US voters seem pervaded by a very deep apathy about collective responsibility towards raising the next generation.

For Amber, and for Karl, yes, this person was a stranger. It was his first few HOURS at a new place with new people when this happened. She also states in her article that it isn't about safety in childcare facilities. It's about our culture and its implications for working mothers.

Good on you though, for ensuring the safety of hundreds of children over the course of your career by making sure your staff were both educated and loving; both are so important for youngsters. I am happy to know that there are folks out there running departments who truly care about the people they take care of :)
The daycare staff did not know her baby.  They knew him for 2.5 hours.  They were strangers.  It's not comforting to tell this mother that the staff must have loved him.

My children each had to go to daycare at the age of 6 weeks. They were loved and cared for; I know this, because I worked close by and was lucky enough to talk my employer into allowing me to breastfeed on demand, so I was always dropping in. Other than staying home with them myself -- which was not possible -- I cannot imagine a better place they could have been.

First, let me say that I am so incredibly sorry for your loss. No parent should ever have to endure that kind of grief. Sending love and healing to you and your family.

Second, you state in the article that your son 'died in the care of a stranger.' I worked in day care (I was head of the infant department) for more than a decade, and I assure you that the people who love and care for your children during the day are far from strangers. It sounds like this was a horrible incident of a childcare center that both used unsafe sleep practices and was unprepared for an emergency. I have worked in five different locations in several states across the US, and in every one we followed strict safety procedures and insisted that every staff member receive ongoing education about child safety and development. In many cases, I found myself gently educating parents about safer methods to parent their babies.

More importantly: I (and I believe all my staff) loved those children. Every one. Nothing brought me greater joy than seeing them happy and healthy, than hearing their giggles and gurgles. I still remember all the children I cared for at my first daycare job 25 years ago. Now that I am older and have raised two children of my own, I am able to look back and say I could not have cared for those babies in day care any better if they were my own children.

I know you had an awful experience. But please know that many childcarers are amazing - and safe.

My deepest condolences to this young couple. If Amber or Lee could have been with Karl, at least the parent who was with him would have the slightest peace of mind in knowing everything humanly possible was done to prevent his death. Perhaps with papertiger's help the young parents could have thought of some alternative that eluded them; the point is it shouldn't be so hard. People without college degrees should be able to have babies. It used to be a family could make ends meet on one semi-educated worker's wages in the US. That is no longer so. With inadequate wages, inadequate education, inadequate childcare options, and inadequate healthcare, something has to give; apparently, that 'something' is the most vulnerable citizens, and only the well-off should have kids. The greatest country in the world indeed. If you think that you've probably not traveled or read much or you've got a family member risking his or her life in the armed forces, so you can't bear to think otherwise. Pity the working class American.
